metadata.title: Characterization of Pulse and Direct Current Methods for Electrodeposition of Ni-Co Composite Coatings Reinforced with Nano and Micro ZnO Particles

sections.heading: Characterization of Pulse and Direct Current
Methods for Electrodeposition of Ni-Co Composite
Coatings Reinforced with Nano and Micro ZnO
Particles
sections.text:
SIAVASH IMANIAN GHAZANLOU, A.H.S. FARHOOD, SOMAYEH AHMADIYEH, EHSAN ZIYAEI, ALI RASOOLI, and SAMAN HOSSEINPOUR
Ni-Co composite coatings reinforced with ZnO particles are prepared by either pulsed current (PC) or direct current (DC) electrodeposition methods. X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), and EDX mapping are employed to investigate phase structure, surface morphology, elemental composition, and elemental distribution of coating, respectively. The effects of electrodeposition parameters such as stirring rate, average current density, and ZnO particles concentration on the microhardness of electrodeposited composite coating reinforced with nano and micro ZnO particles are investigated. Optimal values are determined for all of the above-mentioned parameters, which result in the maximum hardness of the coating. Any deviation from the optimal parameters leads to a reduction of the coating’s microhardness. The SEM, atomic force microscopy (AFM), wear test, and electrochemical examinations revealed that changing the electrodeposition method from DC to PC and varying the size of ZnO particles from micro to nano affect the surface morphology from rough to smooth and reduce the surface friction coefficient, both of which enhanced the wear resistance of the coating and improved its corrosion resistance. The SEM results from worn surfaces illustrated that the size of reinforcing ZnO particles and the electroplating method change the wear mechanisms and worn surface morphology.
https://doi.org/10.1007/s11661-019-05118-y The Minerals, Metals & Materials Society and ASM International 2019
I. INTRODUCTION
ELECTRODEPOSITION is one of the most reliable ways of acquiring nanostructured coatings with enhanced mechanical and electrochemical properties. The obtained structures through electrodeposition, and their corresponding properties have been widely studied in the last decades.[1] In recent years, electrodeposition has been utilized in producing metal matrix nanocomposite coatings.[2,3] Due to their noticeable wear and
corrosion resistances, the electrodeposited nanocomposite coatings have found a wide range of applications in automotive industries, e.g., in engines and casting modules.[3] Electrodeposition process for applying metal matrix composite is often characterized by four steps: (1) particle surface charge formation in suspension, (2) particle transfer thorough the suspension toward the cathode surface, (3) particles interaction with cathode surface, and (4) entrapment of nanoparticles in the germinating metal layer,[4] all of which are sensitive to the electrodeposition parameters. Thus, alterations in electrodeposition parameters affect the final structure and properties of the composite coating. Several researches, for instance, have indicated that increasing the current density during electrodeposition leads to reduction of coating microhardness.[3,5–16] Yang and Cheng[17] showed that in electroplating of Ni-Co/SiC nanocomposite coating, increasing the pulse frequency and reducing the duty cycle result in a higher SiC entrapment in the coating, which consequently enhance the coating’s microhardness. It should be mentioned that the hardness of the electrodeposited coating depends on the applied current alteration method, and in majority of the investigated cases, the maximum SIAVASH IMANIAN GHAZANLOU is with the Faculty of Materials Engineering, Sahand University of Technology, P.O. Box: 51335-1996, Tabriz, Iran. Contact e-mail: s.imanian.sut@gmail.com A.H.S. FARHOOD is with the Department of Materials Engineering, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran. SOMAYEH AHMADIYEH and ALI RASOOLI are with the Department of Materials Engineering, University of Tabriz, Tabriz, Iran. EHSAN ZIYAEI is with the Department of Materials Engineering, Isfahan University of Technology (IUT), Isfahan, Iran. SAMAN HOSSEINPOUR is with the Institute of Particle Technology (LFG), Friedrich–Alexander– Universität Erlangen-Nürnberg (FAU), Cauerstrasse 4, 91058 Erlangen, Germany Manuscript submitted October 25, 2018.
METALLURGICAL AND MATERIALS TRANSACTIONS A
hardness is achieved in this order: pulse reverse current (PRC)> pulsed current (PC)> direct current (DC) methods.[18] Similar results are confirmed by Kumar et al.,[19] who showed a higher microhardness of Ni-W/ TiO2 coating using PC method compared with DC procedure.
Several studies also demonstrated that addition of particles into coatings during electrodeposition method decreases the grain size of the coatings and enhances their microhardness[2,6,9,12,14,19–32]. However, to the best of our knowledge, the impact of ZnO particles on properties of Ni-Co/ZnO composite coatings obtained by DC or PC-electrodeposition techniques is not yet fully investigated. Therefore, in this study, we assess the effects of stirring rate, average current density, and ZnO (micro or nano) particles’ concentration in electrodeposition bath on the properties of Ni-Co-reinforced coatings prepared by either DC or PC methods. Special attention is thus paid to the effect of electrodeposition methods and variations of ZnO particle’s size on the surface morphology and microstructure, surface roughness, microhardness, friction coefficient, wear resistance, wear mechanisms, and corrosion behavior of nanocomposite coatings.

sections.heading: II. MATERIALS AND METHODS
sections.text:
Materials: Ni-Co composite coatings reinforced with micro or nano ZnO particles were electrodeposited on the surface of 10 mm 9 10 mm 9 1 mm pure copper cathodes as substrates, by pulse and direct current electrodeposition methods. Before electrodeposition, Cu sheets were polished by emery papers (200, 800, and 1200) and then were soaked in ethanol and 10 pct HCl for 2 minutes and 15 seconds, respectively, followed by a cleaning step in distilled water. A sheet of 25 mm 9 25 mm 9 1 mm pure nickel was utilized as the anode. Both direct and pulse patterns were generated by a power supply (ICP Company). Table I illustrates the composition of the bath (100 mL) that was utilized as electrolyte for electrodeposition. The electrolyte was stirred by a magnetic stirrer during electrodeposition process.
ZnO particles with the nominal average size of either 20 nm or 500 nm were added to the coating’s matrix, as reinforcing particles. For simplicity, hereafter these ZnO particles are referred to as nano ZnO and micro ZnO, respectively. The SEM micrographs of the nano and micro ZnO particles are provided in Figure 1.
Process parameters: The following constant parameters: electrolyte temperature of 50 C, electrolyte pH of 4.2, pulse frequency of 10 Hz, duty cycle of 50 pct, and electroplating time of 90 minutes were applied for electrodeposition of all coatings. Varying electrodeposition parameters including stirring rate, average current density, and ZnO particles concentration were applied to prepare nanocopmposite coatings with different ZnO particle sizes (i.e., nano or micro) through different electrodeposition methods (i.e., PC or DC). To evaluate the effect of stirring rate on the properties of
electrodeposited coating, stirring rates of 100, 200, 300, or 400 revolutions per minute (rpm) were selected, for electrodeposition in constant average current density of 3.5 A/dm2 and ZnO particle concentration of 12.5 g/ L. To assess the effect of average current density on the coatings properties, current values of 2, 3, 4, or 5 A/dm2 were applied at constant stirring rate of 250 rpm and ZnO particle concentration of 12.5 g/L. Finally, ZnO particle concentrations of 5, 10, 15, 20 g/L were applied at constant average current density of 3.5 A/dm2 and stirring rate of 250 rpm, to investigate the effect of particle concentration on the coating properties. Optimal electrodeposition parameters were then identified to reach coatings with maximum microhardness. Electrolyte preparation: 15 mg sodium dodecylsulfate (SDS, 98 pct Scharlau), 50 mL distilled water, and nano or micro ZnO particles with desired concentrations were primarily mixed in a beaker and were stirred for 24 hours at agitation rate of 1200 rpm. Then, Watt’s bath materials were added to the beaker with distilled water up the volume of 100 mL. Finally, the bath temperature was increased to 50 C and was being kept steady during the process. After electroplating, coatings were heat treated in 450 C for 4 hours under argon in a furnace to improve the adhesion between the coatings and substrates. Mechanical and structural evaluations: The Vickers microhardness for each specimen was measured 10 times through applying a vertical load of 100 g for 10 seconds, using a Buhler instrument, and the average value was reported as the mean hardness result. In order to explore the phase structure of the composite coatings, X-ray diffractometer with a Cu-Ka radiation wavelength of 0.154 nm was employed. Scherrer’s equation was used to calculate the crystallite size[33]:
t ¼ 0:9k B cos hB ; ½1
where t is the crystallite size in nanometers, k is the wavelength (0.154 nm) of CuKa radiation, B is the full width half maximum (FWHM) at 2hB radians, and hB is the Bragg’s angle.[33] In addition, surface morphology and elemental distribution of coatings were evaluated using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX). Atomic force microscopy (AFM) was employed in a contact mode to investigate the roughness of coatings. The wear resistance of coatings was measured using a pin-on-disk test according to ASTM standard G99-95. Briefly, a load of 50 N at ambient condition was applied on sample by a pin, AISI 52100 steel (62 HRC), with a fixed diameter of 1.8 cm and a rotation speed of 50 rpm for 1000 cycle. A copper substrate, with diameter of 30 mm and thickness of 2 mm, coated with the electrodeposited composite film was used as disk. Acetone solution and ultrasonic agitation were used for washing and cleaning specimens. Fraction dislodged materials were quantified by subtracting the final weight of
METALLURGICAL AND MATERIALS TRANSACTIONS A
specimens after the wear test from their initials weight, using 0.001 g precision scale (the average of three weight values were reported to reduce the data scattering effect).
In order to measure anodic polarization, Potentiostat Gavanostat Parstat 2273 device was exploited. The electrochemical tests were performed in a 3.5 wt pct NaCl solution at ambient temperature with a scanning rate of 0.5 mV/s, using Ni-Co/ZnO composite coatings as working electrode. Saturated calomel electrode (SCE) was employed as the reference electrode and the counter electrode was a platinum wire. Specimens were soaked in a 3.5 wt pct NaCl solution for 30 minutes prior to polarization measurement to reach a steady state, after which the open circuit potential (OCP) measurement was carried out. Finally, polarization examinations were performed. The domain of used potential was from 250 mV to 250 mV relative to OCP and then the polarization curves were begun at corrosion potential. The corrosion potential was extracted from the polarization curves using Tafel extrapolation, and the polarization resistance (RP) was calculated employing Stern–Geary equation[13]:
RP ¼ babc
2:303icorrðba þ bcÞ ; ½2
where ba and bc are anodic and cathodic Tafel slopes, respectively. The corrosion rate (rcorr in mm per year) was determined through the following equation[13]:
rcorr ¼ 0:00327 icorrM
nd ; ½3
where M, n, and d are molar mass, charge number, and density of tested metal, respectively. For the purpose of simplification and to emphasize the important affecting parameters, XRD, SEM, EDX, EDX mapping, friction coefficient, AFM, wear mass loss, wear morphology, and Tafel results obtained on three selected samples are provided here: (1) PC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite, (2) DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite, and (3) DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/micro ZnO particle composite. All the samples were prepared under the following constant conditions: stirring rate—300 rpm, average current density—3.5 A/dm2, and ZnO particle concentration at bath—12.5 g/L.
Fig. 1—SEM images of (a) nano ZnO particles and (b) micro ZnO particles.
Table I. Chemical Composition of the Electrolyte Utilized in Electrodeposition Bath
Material Producer Purity (Percent) Amount in the Electrolyte (g/L)
NiSO4Æ6H2O Scharlau 98 140 NiCl2Æ6H2O BDH 98 50 H3BO3 (boric acid) Merck 99.8 30 CoSO4Æ7H2O Scharlau 98 30 Sodium dodecyl sulfate (SDS) surfactant Scharlau 98 0.3 ZnO micro and nanoparticles Merck 99.5 variable
METALLURGICAL AND MATERIALS TRANSACTIONS A

sections.heading: III. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text:
A. XRD
The XRD patterns of Ni-Co-electrodeposited coatings reinforced with micro or nano ZnO particles under PC and DC electrodeposition conditions are shown in Figure 2. Diffraction peaks of Nickel-cobalt alloy (111) & (200), ZnO (101) & (201), NiO and CoO compounds (220) & (311) & (222) are identified in all coatings. The sharpest peak of ZnO (101) relates to PC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO, which reflects the highest amount of ZnO compared to DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO, and PC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/ micro ZnO. NiO and CoO phases are most likely formed during heat treatment process of coatings.
The crystallite sizes derived from XRD patterns and Eq. [1] are presented in Figure 3. According to this figure, for DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/micro ZnO particle coating, the crystallite size is 29 nm. Addition of nano ZnO particles, instead of micro ZnO particles, decreased the crystallite size to 24 nm. The smallest crystalline size (20 nm), however, was obtained through PC electrodeposition of Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating.
The classical Zener pinning pressure on unit area of the grain boundary for a volume fraction (FV) of randomly distributed spherical particles with radius r can be obtained using following equation[34]:
PZ ¼ 3FVc 2r ; ½4
where c is energy of grain boundary.[34] Zener limiting grain size is accordingly calculated through following equation[34]:
DZ ¼ 4r
3FV ½5
According to Eqs. [4] and [5], Zener pinning pressure is enhanced by reduction of the ZnO particle size and increase of their volume fraction in the deposit. These conditions are met using PC electroplating with nanosized ZnO particles resulting in reduction of Ni-Co grain size.

sections.heading: B. SEM, EDX, and EDX Mapping
sections.text:
Figure 4 shows the surface morphology of composite coatings with nano and micro ZnO particles electrodeposited using PC or DC method, at two different magnifications (i.e., 1 K and 5 K, respectively). Two distinct morphologies can be seen in Figures 4(a) and (b); A smooth flat surface and globular structures grown
Fig. 3—Crystallite size of Ni-Co matrix extracted from XRD results: (a) PC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/ nano ZnO, (b) DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/ nano ZnO, and (c) DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/ micro ZnO.
METALLURGICAL AND MATERIALS TRANSACTIONS A
METALLURGICAL AND MATERIALS TRANSACTIONS A
on the flat surface. The EDX results illustrate that coating components are indeed Ni-Co/ZnO. Generally, as is shown, exploiting ZnO nanoparticles to reinforce the coating using PC method leads to creation of an unwrinkled surface with lower roughness, compared to its counterpart coatings. Due to the low deposition rate in PC method, positive ions (e.g., Ni2+ and Co2+) together with ZnO particles are expected to deposit slowly. The presence of fine dispersion of ZnO nanoparticles is thus very advantageous in refining the grains by producing abundant locations for heterogeneous nucleation. Few small cracks that are observed on the surface might have been generated when growing Ni-Co clusters with different orientations reached each other. Nevertheless, crack formation in the coating due to vacuum pressure in the SEM setup cannot be ruled out. According to Figures 4(c) and (d), switching the current type to DC, while maintaining nano ZnO particles as reinforcement, results in substantial changes in surface morphology of the coating. Higher densities of globular structures, which appear rougher and more disordered, are characteristics of the Ni-Co composite coatings reinforced with nano ZnO particles prepared by DC method. Indeed, applying DC current increases the (Ni2+ and Co2+) deposition rate, and thus the morphology becomes globular accompanied by some cracks on surface. Utilizing micro ZnO particles instead of nano ZnO particles, while maintaining the deposition method as DC, urges the surface morphology to be even rougher and more disordered, with characteristic cauliflower shape deposits, as is observed in Figures 4(e) and (f). Creation of cauliflower-like morphology is owing to the fact that by using DC method, the rate of deposition increases and by incorporating of ZnO microparticles, the number of sufficient places for heterogenous nucleation decreases; therefore, the morphology becomes more disordered. According to Figure 5, the ZnO particles adopt a more uniform distribution when they are in the form of nano ZnO particle and are deposited through PC method. The uniform distribution of nano ZnO particles in turn produces more positions for heterogeneous nucleation. It is thus expected that ZnO particles with greater size result in rougher surfaces with larger number of cracks, consistent with the results in Figures 4(e) and (f).
Quantitative analysis of the EDX results confirms higher content of ZnO in PC-deposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating (8 wt pct) compared to that in DC-deposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating (4 wt pct) or DC-deposited Ni-Co/micro ZnO particle composite coating (3 wt pct), in agreement with the XRD results in Figure 2.
Figure 6 schematically shows the entrapping mechanisms of ZnO particles in Ni-Co growing layers, which involves the four steps that were presented in the Introduction section. As an anionic surfactant (SDS) is added to electrolyte, it adsorbs on the surface of ZnO particles, making them negatively charged. In turn, electrostatic forces in solution attract a larger number of cationic ions (Ni2+ and Co2+) toward ZnO particles, compared to the adsorbed cations on the surface of surfactant free ZnO particles. Due to the larger surface
area in nano ZnO particles, the number of attracted cations of these particles is higher than those on their micro ZnO particle counterparts. Consequently, a larger number of adsorbed cations on nano ZnO particles would electrostatically entrap in the growing Ni-Co layer on the cathode surface. The above-mentioned interactions are mainly governed by electrostatic forces. It should be noted that regardless of the density and type of surface charges, agitation of electrolyte during electrodeposition enhances the frequency of collision of ZnO particles and the adsorbed ions on the cathode surface and promotes entrapment of particles and ions in the pores and notches of growing Ni-Co layers. Hydrodynamic forces in electrolyte are dominant in these types of interactions. Eventually, the Ni2+ ions which depart the nickel surface are reduced at the cathode, resulting in dwindling of the anode during electrodeposition.[33,35–37]

sections.heading: C. Microhardness Study
sections.text:
1. Effect of stirring rate on the microhardness of composite coating According to Bakhit et al.,[22] electrolyte stirring leads to (i) homogeneity of electrolyte (ii) enhancement of mass transfer in the bulk electrolyte (iii) reduction of the concentration boundary films’ thickness, and (iv) better release of hydrogen from cathode surface, all of which are expected to increase the microhardness of the composite film. It is also expected that stirring of solution incorporating ZnO particles should lead to the breaking up and division of agglomerated clusters to smaller pieces. Therefore, stirring rate is anticipated to have an effect on the final structure of the composite coating. In Figure 7 the effect of stirring rate on the microhardness of composite coatings prepared by DCor PC-electrodeposition methods is presented. As seen from this figure, an optimal stirring rate is found based on the maximum microhardness of the composite coating: 200 rpm for Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating prepared by PC method, 300 rpm for Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating prepared by DC method, and 400 rpm for Ni-Co/micro ZnO particle composite coating prepared by DC method. Indeed, increasing the stirring rate up to the optimal value not only breaks up the particle agglomerate, but also facilitates their transport and sticking into the pores of the growing Ni-Co matrix by intensifying mobility in the electrolyte. When the stirring rate surpasses the optimal values, elastic clashes between particles with high kinetic energy and the cathode surface may thrust the particles back away from the cathode reducing the probability of their adherence. Consequently, the coating will be dislodged as both particles’ entrapment and deposition mechanisms in the growing Ni-Co layers are disturbed. Therefore, excessive stirring rate reduces the number of particles in the coating and decreases its microhardness. Similar observations were made by other researchers, where an optimal stirring rate was found for a given electrodeposition system.[3,5–7,13,38]
Figure 7 also shows that by replacing the micro ZnO particles with nano ZnO particles, the overall
METALLURGICAL AND MATERIALS TRANSACTIONS A
microhardness of coating is enhanced. This is related, on the one hand, to a better distribution of particles with smaller size in the matrix, as was described earlier. On the other hand, dislocation pile-up in coatings reinforced with smaller particles creates diverse stress-concentrated areas which further enhance the hardness of coatings.[39]
2. Effect of electrodeposition methods on the microhardness of composite coatings
In pulse current method, the current is alternated between off and on states. Current ‘on’ is dominated by direct electroplating of Ni from anode on the cathode with limited incorporation of ZnO particles from the solution. When the current is ‘off’, the rate of direct Ni
deposition is limited, and the reduction of ZnO particles surrounded by cations (Ni2+ and Co2+) on the cathode becomes the dominant process. However, when the electrodeposition is performed using direct current method, direct Ni deposition is always the dominant over the reduction of ZnO particle. Consequently, the number of incorporated ZnO particles in the coating matrix becomes limited, reducing the overall microhardness, compared with PC method,[33,35] in agreement with the results shown in Figure 7. Furthermore, according to Figure 7, switching the electroplating method from PC to DC in nano ZnO particle composite coatings shifts the optimal stirring rate from 200 rpm to 300 rpm. During the on/off cycles in pulse current method, electrostatic attraction force between cathode
METALLURGICAL AND MATERIALS TRANSACTIONS A
surface and positive ions alters from maximum to minimum, respectively, while it remains maximum throughout the DC deposition method. Therefore, for a given deposition time, electrostatic attraction forces in DC method are more dominant than those in PC method. Thereby, when DC deposition method is applied, higher stirring rate is required to maximize the incorporation of nano ZnO particles, together with their surrounding cationic cloud, in the pores of cathode. The higher optimal stirring rate to the maximum microhardness for coatings with micro ZnO particles compared with their nano ZnO particle counterparts (400 rpm vs 300 rpm, respectively), can be explained by Newton’s second law (F = ma). According to this law, a larger force should be applied for bigger particles to reach the speed which counteracts their deposition, as was discussed in Section III–C–1.
3. Effect of average current density on the microhardness of composite coatings According to Figure 8, at a constant stirring rate, an optimal average current density can be identified to reach the maximum microhardness of composite coatings. This optimal value corresponds to 4 A/dm2 for PC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating and DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/micro ZnO particle composite coating and to 3 A/dm2 for DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating. Applying electrical current lower than optimal values reduces the attraction forces between ZnO particles and cathode, which limits the incorporation on reinforcing particles, and consequently lowers the microhardness of the composite coating, in accordance with Guglielmi’s model.[40] When the average current density reaches its optimal value, electrostatic force of attraction between particles and cathode reaches maximum. Furthermore, the chance of transfer from the
Fig. 7—The effect of stirring rate on the microhardness of Ni-Co/ ZnO coatings.
METALLURGICAL AND MATERIALS TRANSACTIONS A
loose adsorption steps to the stronger ones increases.[39] Therefore, the maximum amount of ZnO particles are incorporated into the composite coating, improving its microhardness. Further escalation of current density beyond the optimal value unleashes the rate of electroplating and causes the positive nickel and cobalt ions to surge toward cathode surface much faster than nanoparticles, which results in depletion of entrapped nanoparticles in the growing coating layers and reduces microhardness. It should be noted that the average applied current density and the agitation rate have overlapping effect on controlling the motion of the ions and particles toward the cathode during electrodeposition.[9,10,13,21] The higher optimal current density in PC method (4 A/dm2) compared to that of DC method (3 A/dm2) in electrodeposition of nano ZnO particles can be explained by the higher attractive force between particles and cathode in the DC method vs that in PC method, as was discussed earlier. Furthermore, the on/ off cycles in PC method may cause agitation of hydrodynamic forces close to cathode, which is overcome at higher average current densities. Changing the size of ZnO particles also affects the optimal current
density value. The bigger and heavier ZnO particles require higher current density to overcome the shear stress of agitating electrolyte compared with smaller ZnO particles. Besides, due to the lower surface-to-volume ratio in bigger ZnO particles, fewer positive ions per unit area can be transferred together with particles compared to that for smaller particles deposited with the similar current density.
4. Effect of ZnO particles’ concentration in electrolyte on the microhardness of composite coating
Figure 9 demonstrates how the microhardness of composite coatings alters as a function of ZnO concentration in electrolyte. According to Guglielmi’s model, increasing the particle concentration in the electrodeposition bath increases the amount of embedded particles in the deposited composite layers.[5,7,26,40] Consistent with this model, the microhardness of the composite coating is enhanced for micro and nano ZnO particles in DC deposition method. It is also observed that, within the tested concentration range in this study, nano and micro ZnO particles follow the same concentration-dependence law. The negative effect of the increased nano ZnO particle concentration that is observed beyond 15 g/L is due to undesirable phenomena such as increase in the electrolyte viscosity and particles agglomeration.[11,21] This finding is in contrast to the results observed in[26] and,[41] where no upper limit was found for the concentration of the reinforcing particles in the electrodeposition bath. We supposed that this discrepancy will be resolved if higher particle concentrations are considered in those studies.

sections.heading: D. Wear Resistance Evaluation
sections.text:
Wear is the result of material loss when two materials slide over each other under their own weight or under an external load. The wear of a specimen can be quantified
METALLURGICAL AND MATERIALS TRANSACTIONS A
by weight loss or wear volume. Based on Archard’s theory for adhesive wear, the wear volume (V) of a material is calculated according to[42]:
V ¼ c PL H ; ½6
where c denotes the wear coefficient, P is the applied load, and L is the sliding distance. Furthermore, friction derives from junctions shearing under applied forces. Assuming a multiasperity-contacting mode, the relationship between normal forces and frictional forces can be derived as[43]
F ¼ lN; ½7
where F, N, and l are the frictional force, the normal force, and the coefficient of friction, respectively. The friction coefficients of Ni-Co/ZnO particle composite coatings vs cycle under non-lubricated conditions at ambient temperature and 50 N load are presented in Figure 10. In all cases, 2000 cycles were applied, and total passed distance (2000 9 2 9 p 9 r = 2000 9 2 9 p 9 9 9 10 3 m) was about 113.1 m. As seen in Figure 10, the friction coefficients for all coatings rise initially as the result of repeated collisions between two substrates. After this initial period, some of
Fig. 12—Wear mass loss of (a) PC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/ nano ZnO, (b) DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/ nano ZnO, and (c) DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/ micro ZnO. in wear conditions when subjected to a load of 50 N under ambient condition and without lubrication condition.
METALLURGICAL AND MATERIALS TRANSACTIONS A
METALLURGICAL AND MATERIALS TRANSACTIONS A
ZnO particles are dislodged from the deposit and act as self-lubricating agents,[44,45] stabilizing the friction coefficient. It is also observed that micro ZnO particles have lower impact on friction coefficient dwindling in comparison with nano ZnO particles, due to their inferior self-lubricant aspect stemming from their large size. The self-lubrication effect is more pronounced for coating deposited using PC method, due to the denser and more uniformly distributed particles within the composite coating matrix. The order of the number of cycles in which the stabilized friction coefficient is reached is PC-deposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particles composite coating>DC-deposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particles composite coating>DC-deposited Ni-Co/micro ZnO particles composite coating. As shown in Figure 10, the highest friction coefficient is reached in the reverse order (i.e., PC-deposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particles composite coating<DC-deposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particles composite coating<DC-deposited Ni-Co/micro ZnO particles composite coating). As was discussed in previous sections, finer ZnO particles will have a more uniform distribution within the composite coating and result in a smoother coating surface. This observation is confirmed by AFM studies of the coatings, as depicted in Figure 11. The surface roughness will in turn affect the friction coefficient of the coating. Comparing AFM images (Figures 11(a) through (c) correspond to PC-electrodeposited nanocomposite, Figures 11(d) through (f) correspond to DC-electrodeposited nanocomposite, and Figures 11(g) through (i) correspond to DC-electrodeposited microcomposite), indicate that the surface of Ni-Co/ZnO microcomposite
coating has the roughest and the most disordered surface which results in the increase of the friction coefficient between coating and disk while the second and third places belong to DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/ nano ZnO and PC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO, respectively. According to Figure 12, the minimum mass loss (highest wear resistance) is achieved in PC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating, followed by DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite and DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/micro ZnO particle composite, respectively, which is consistent with the microhardness assessment of the coatings, as was discussed in the previous sections. These results are in agreement with previous studies where coatings reinforced with nanoparticles showed higher resistance to wear and corrosion at elevated temperature, and had superior strength, hardness, and electrochemical behavior than the pure alloy.[28,46–48]
Figure 13 demonstrates the worn morphology of coatings after the wear test. Surface of PC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating, illustrated in Figures 13(a) and (b), has fewer grooves and wear debris with some local deformations, and limited coating failures and flakes compared with other coatings. Multiple mechanisms such as adhesion, delamination, and abrasion contribute to the wear on this type of coating. Some flakes, few wear debris, and pores can be observed on the worn surface of DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating (Figures 13(c) and (d)). Wear mechanism in this coating is mainly delamination. Worn surface of DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/micro ZnO particle composite coating (Figures 13(e) and (f)) with the minimum microhardness and highest friction coefficient, however, shows greatest local coating failure (detachment) and the highest number of flakes and debris in harshest wear behavior with mechanisms of delamination and adhesion.

sections.heading: E. Corrosion Resistance Investigation
sections.text:
Figure 14 and Table II show the Tafel curves of Ni-Co/ZnO composite coatings and the determined corrosion parameters, respectively. In Table II, the polarization resistance (RP) and corrosion rate (rcorr) are presented.
According to Figure 14 and Table II, the highest
corrosion potential and the lowest corrosion current density and corrosion rate correspond to PC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating. DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating and DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/micro ZnOFig. 14—Tafel diagrams of coatings in a 3.5 wt pct NaCl solution.
Table II. Corrosion Parameters Extracted from Polarization Curves Shown in Fig. 14
Parameters/Specimens Ecorr (mV) icorr (lA/cm 2) RP (kX cm 2) rcorr (mm/year)
PC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating 760 0.026 601.22 0.2883 DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO particle composite coating 760 0.081 113.11 0.9849 DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/micro ZnO particle composite coating 860 0.621 13.29 7.2127
METALLURGICAL AND MATERIALS TRANSACTIONS A
particle composite coatings are next in the order of ranking. As was discussed earlier, nano ZnO particle composite coatings prepared by the PC method contain the highest amount of trapped ZnO particles into the growing Ni-Co layers, which enhances the corrosion resistance in these coatings. Impregnated hard-ceramic particles in the coating act as corrosion-resisting substances, owing to their low chemical activity compared with the matrix, as was observed in other studies.[5,7,12,17,28,30,49,50] Since the pores and defects on metal surface are often active corrosion-initiation sites, embedded ceramic particles, especially those which can embed in the small holes in the coating,[13] contribute to a better corrosion resistance of the coating, confirming the results as seen in Figure 14 and Table II. Another important factor in the enhancement of the corrosion resistance of the composite coatings is the effect of particles on refining the grain sizes in the coating. In general, grain size reduction improves the corrosion resistance of coating[51] as passive layers often nucleate and grow at grain boundaries, and therefore, grain refinement results in a more homogeneous passive layer.[52] Furthermore, addition of ZnO particles into coating matrix improves the hydrophobicity of the coating, as was observed by Zhao et al.[53]

sections.heading: IV. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text:
SEM results show that surface morphology of PC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO was mostly flat, and partly globular, while DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO had a globular morphology, and the surface morphology of DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO was cauliflower-like. There were optimal values for stirring rate, average current density, and ZnO particles concentration to achieve the maximum microhardness. Any deviation from these optimal values led to the reduction of the microhardness of composite coatings. By switching the electrodeposition method from PC to DC, the optimal stirring rate needed to reach the maximum microhardness of Ni-Co/ZnO nanocomposite coating decreased from 300 to 200 rpm. By opting for the ZnO microparticles instead of ZnO nanoparticles in DC method, the optimal stirring rate increased from 300 to 400 rpm. By opting for PC method instead of DC, optimal average current density for achieving maximum microhardness of nanocomposite coating increased from 3 to 4 A/dm2. By opting for DC method instead of PC to produce Ni-Co/ZnO nanocomposite coating, optimal value for ZnO nanoparticle concentration increased from 15 to 20 g/L. Opting for ZnO microparticles instead of ZnO nanoparticles does not change the optimal value of particles concentration. Wear mechanisms in worn PC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO was adhesive, delamination, and few were abrasive; but wear mechanism of
DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/nano ZnO was delamination; and activated wear mechanisms for DC-electrodeposited Ni-Co/micro ZnO were delamination and adhesive. Incorporation of ZnO nanoparticles in the Ni-Co matrix by PC-electroplating method improved the corrosion and wear resistances of coating to more than those obtained using ZnO microparticles by DC method.

sections.heading: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
sections.text: The authors are grateful to the Sahand University of Technology and University of Tabriz for their cooperation to perform the experimental section. SH thanks Emerging Talents Initiative (ETI) 2018/ 2_Tech_06, FAU, Germany grant for supporting his research.

sections.heading: CONFLICT OF INTEREST
sections.text: We have no conflict of interest to disclose.

In recent years, electrodeposition has been utilized in producing metal matrix nanocomposite coatings.([2,3]) Due to their noticeable wear and corrosion resistances, the electrodeposited nanocomposite coatings have found a wide range of applications in automotive industries, e.

In recent years, electrodeposition has been utilized in producing metal matrix nanocomposite coatings.([2,3]) Due to their noticeable wear and corrosion resistances, the electrodeposited nanocomposite coatings have found a wide range of applications in automotive industries, e.

, in engines and casting modules.([3]) Electrodeposition process for applying metal matrix composite is often characterized by four steps: (1) particle surface charge formation in suspension, (2) particle transfer thorough the suspension toward the cathode surface, (3) particles interaction with cathode surface, and (4) entrapment of nanoparticles in the germinating metal layer,([4]) all of which are sensitive to the electrodeposition parameters.

Applying electrical current lower than optimal values reduces the attraction forces between ZnO particles and cathode, which limits the incorporation on reinforcing particles, and consequently lowers the microhardness of the composite coating, in accordance with Guglielmi’s model.([40]) When the average current density reaches its optimal value, electrostatic force of attraction between particles and cathode reaches maximum.

metadata.abstractText: Ni-Co composite coatings reinforced with ZnO particles are prepared by either pulsed current (PC) or direct current (DC) electrodeposition methods. X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), and EDX mapping are employed to investigate phase structure, surface morphology, elemental composition, and elemental distribution of coating, respectively. The effects of electrodeposition parameters such as stirring rate, average current density, and ZnO particles concentration on the microhardness of electrodeposited composite coating reinforced with nano and micro ZnO particles are investigated. Optimal values are determined for all of the above-mentioned parameters, which result in the maximum hardness of the coating. Any deviation from the optimal parameters leads to a reduction of the coating’s microhardness. The SEM, atomic force microscopy (AFM), wear test, and electrochemical examinations revealed that changing the electrodeposition method from DC to PC and varying the size of ZnO particles from micro to nano affect the surface morphology from rough to smooth and reduce the surface friction coefficient, both of which enhanced the wear resistance of the coating and improved its corrosion resistance. The SEM results from worn surfaces illustrated that the size of reinforcing ZnO particles and the electroplating method change the wear mechanisms and worn surface morphology.
metadata.creator: Springer
